description: ISO/IEC 20000:2011 is the International Standard for IT service management. In this accredited show we explore the requirements for an organization to achieve the ISO/IEC 20000 certification. This show is designed as a 1st step for managers and internal auditors who are considering gaining accreditation for their organization and as an overview for IT staff who’s organization is working towards accreditation. This show will also prepare individuals for the ISO/IEC 20000 examination.

episodes.title: Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:03.050
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.050 --> 00:00:07.120
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco

3
00:00:07.120 --> 00:00:08.354
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:08.354 --> 00:00:11.931
>> Welcome to your ISO/IEC

5
00:00:11.931 --> 00:00:18.900
20000:2011 Foundation series.

6
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:21.050
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:21.050 --> 00:00:25.400
In this episode, we have ISO
expert Jo Peacock to come in and

8
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:28.840
introduce what the series
is really all about.

9
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:30.060
So, thank you for joining us today, Jo.

10
00:00:30.060 --> 00:00:31.000
How are you doing?

11
00:00:31.000 --> 00:00:34.740
>> Well, I'm doing fine, but
I want to help you out right now, okay?

12
00:00:34.740 --> 00:00:37.150
Because that's quite a bit of a mouthful,
isn't it?

13
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:38.000
>> It was a mouthful.

14
00:00:38.000 --> 00:00:40.000
>> Yeah, ISO, ICE.

15
00:00:40.000 --> 00:00:44.110
20000 2011, yeah let's call it ISO 20k,
how about that?

16
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:44.610
>> Okay.

17
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:46.770
>> Even ISO 20000.

18
00:00:46.770 --> 00:00:51.670
We should really technically
use the right terminology for

19
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:55.500
this because it is an international
standard so it's the, it's for

20
00:00:55.500 --> 00:00:58.840
the, from the international
organization for standardization.

21
00:00:58.840 --> 00:01:02.010
But however we're just
gonna call it ISO 20000.

22
00:01:02.010 --> 00:01:04.920
>> Yeah, I mean this is
a technical show anyways, so

23
00:01:04.920 --> 00:01:07.820
let's be technical at least once per show.

24
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:08.630
How about that?

25
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:10.580
>> Right, yeah,
we should do that once per show.

26
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:11.910
But nevertheless-
>> [LAUGH]

27
00:01:11.910 --> 00:01:13.790
>> We know that this is a lot for

28
00:01:13.790 --> 00:01:15.290
everybody to get their mouths around.

29
00:01:15.290 --> 00:01:18.330
And for those of you that
are trying to achieve ISO 20000,

30
00:01:18.330 --> 00:01:20.440
then you're gonna be calling it ISO 20000.

31
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:24.540
You're certainly not gonna be banding
that around the office all the time.

32
00:01:24.540 --> 00:01:26.405
>> We have enough to think about, right?

33
00:01:26.405 --> 00:01:29.510
>> [LAUGH] So yeah,
I'm doing fine anyway, how are you?

34
00:01:29.510 --> 00:01:30.300
>> I'm good.

35
00:01:30.300 --> 00:01:35.290
So who are we really focusing this
training for, or these shows for?

36
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:37.730
Who should be interested in
watching these shows, Jo?

37
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:41.270
>> Well, the first thing that I want to do
is just explain a little bit about what

38
00:01:41.270 --> 00:01:43.159
ISO 20,000 is.

39
00:01:43.159 --> 00:01:45.470
>> Okay.
>> And then in this particular episode,

40
00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:50.070
I'm just going to give us just
general overview of who should

41
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:54.050
actually be interested in this show and
who should sort of sit and

42
00:01:54.050 --> 00:01:55.880
watch some of the episodes in this show.

43
00:01:55.880 --> 00:01:56.840
Okay?

44
00:01:56.840 --> 00:02:00.500
So the first thing that I wanna do
as I've said is just to highlight

45
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:02.341
what ISO 20,000 is.

46
00:02:02.341 --> 00:02:06.520
ISO 20,000 is
the international standard for

47
00:02:06.520 --> 00:02:11.340
IT service management,
all right what does that mean and

48
00:02:11.340 --> 00:02:14.430
how does it differ from ITIL
because we've got shows about ITIL.

49
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:17.160
And of course there's been a lot of

50
00:02:17.160 --> 00:02:21.340
talk about ITIL around the world
in the past few years.

51
00:02:21.340 --> 00:02:24.980
Well ITIL is just a framework
it is a framework for

52
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:28.842
managing IT services and
it's at best practice frame work.

53
00:02:30.050 --> 00:02:31.990
But there is no audit for ITIL.

54
00:02:31.990 --> 00:02:35.860
There's nobody that can come in and tell
you whether you're doing ITIL right or

55
00:02:35.860 --> 00:02:41.820
wrong because ITIL is a framework that
you bring into your organization.

56
00:02:41.820 --> 00:02:43.400
You adopt the framework.

57
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:47.570
But then you adapt it in a way
that makes common sense,

58
00:02:47.570 --> 00:02:50.190
perfect sense for your organization.

59
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:55.520
So you adapt it for efficiency and for
effectiveness in your organization.

60
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:57.010
ITIL is not plug and play.

61
00:02:57.010 --> 00:03:01.080
ITIL is not a one-size-fits-all approach
that will solve all of the world's

62
00:03:01.080 --> 00:03:01.650
problems.

63
00:03:02.810 --> 00:03:03.960
Common misconception there.

64
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:05.745
You know,
ITIL's gonna do everything right.

65
00:03:05.745 --> 00:03:09.140
[LAUGH] Well, ITIL doesn't do that.

66
00:03:09.140 --> 00:03:12.250
ITIL is, as I said, just the framework.

67
00:03:12.250 --> 00:03:15.010
We won't tell you what your
processes will look like.

68
00:03:15.010 --> 00:03:16.630
We'll tell you that you
need to have a process.

69
00:03:16.630 --> 00:03:22.590
And we'll tell you how to in I-Tel,
how to define a process as well.

70
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:27.940
So we'll tell you that you need to have
a process for restoring service operation.

71
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:31.930
In other words, for getting people back up
and running when something's gone wrong.

72
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:36.770
And in I-Tel In ITIL mind we
call this incident management.

73
00:03:36.770 --> 00:03:40.380
And so
we'll tell you that you need to work out

74
00:03:40.380 --> 00:03:43.260
what incident management looks like for
your organization.

75
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:48.515
So you will need to have
a process to restore service.

76
00:03:48.515 --> 00:03:51.635
When it goes wrong,
to get it back up and running again.

77
00:03:51.635 --> 00:03:55.955
And so what ITIL does is ITIL says to
you okay, you need to have this process.

78
00:03:55.955 --> 00:04:01.355
Here's some,
I was gonna say hints and tips.

79
00:04:01.355 --> 00:04:05.545
Here's some very useful information that's
going to help you define a process.

80
00:04:06.570 --> 00:04:11.220
Will tell you that you start by working
at what your process should do.

81
00:04:11.220 --> 00:04:15.640
Work at its objective and
then work out the output from the process.

82
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:18.980
So what should the output
from a process look like?

83
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:20.560
Then what about the inputs?

84
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:22.740
The various inputs to a process.

85
00:04:22.740 --> 00:04:27.640
And then, okay, what steps do you need
in your organization to ensure that

86
00:04:27.640 --> 00:04:29.580
we get from the inputs to the outputs.

87
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:32.145
And this is what ITIL will tell you.

88
00:04:32.145 --> 00:04:35.770
ITIL will tell you not only what
processes you should have, but

89
00:04:35.770 --> 00:04:38.770
also how to define those processes.

90
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:43.250
But we won't tell you what your
processes look like, not in ITIL.

91
00:04:43.250 --> 00:04:45.790
So there can't be an audit for ITIL.

92
00:04:45.790 --> 00:04:47.775
Nobody can come along, even me.

93
00:04:47.775 --> 00:04:48.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

94
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:52.640
I like to think of myself as fairly
knowledgeable on the subject.

95
00:04:52.640 --> 00:04:57.460
So I can't come along and say,
yes, that's working great for

96
00:04:57.460 --> 00:04:59.950
your organization using the checklist.

97
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:02.160
I can't do that.

98
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:04.694
I can't audit you from here.

99
00:05:06.950 --> 00:05:09.160
There is no iTel compliance.

100
00:05:10.370 --> 00:05:14.070
And this is something that's a common
misconception amongst everybody that tries

101
00:05:14.070 --> 00:05:17.490
to implement ITIL,
is that you can be ITIL compliant.

102
00:05:17.490 --> 00:05:21.490
And you can't be ITIL compliant,
cuz there's no right or wrong with ITIL.

103
00:05:23.400 --> 00:05:26.130
So, The question that I ask is though,

104
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:28.730
what's the difference between ITIL and
ISO 20000.

105
00:05:28.730 --> 00:05:31.350
Well, that's what ITIL is.

106
00:05:31.350 --> 00:05:33.400
ITIL's a framework for managing services,

107
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:37.155
it's the best practice framework that
you adapt to sync your organization.

108
00:05:37.155 --> 00:05:40.235
So how do you know if
it's working okay then?

109
00:05:40.235 --> 00:05:43.025
How do you know if ITIL is working great?

110
00:05:43.025 --> 00:05:45.915
Well when we have something
that's completely independent,

111
00:05:45.915 --> 00:05:47.545
completely separate.

112
00:05:47.545 --> 00:05:49.665
Has absolutely nothing to do with ITIL.

113
00:05:49.665 --> 00:05:53.775
I say that with a wink all right.

114
00:05:53.775 --> 00:05:57.270
Has absolutely nothing to
do with ITIL whatsoever.

115
00:05:57.270 --> 00:06:01.030
We have an international standard for
service management,

116
00:06:01.030 --> 00:06:02.900
for IT service management.

117
00:06:04.460 --> 00:06:06.010
And with any international standard,

118
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:08.765
an international standard is
something that you attain.

119
00:06:08.765 --> 00:06:11.879
It's something that you achieve,

120
00:06:11.879 --> 00:06:16.987
it's something that you can
say that you can comply with.

121
00:06:16.987 --> 00:06:21.740
ISO 20,000 is a standard,

122
00:06:21.740 --> 00:06:27.240
where you can measure yourself against and
it's a standard for

123
00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:32.950
demonstrating efficiency and
effectiveness and

124
00:06:32.950 --> 00:06:40.170
the relationships in place between
IT service management processes.

125
00:06:40.170 --> 00:06:45.370
So, it's a standard for demonstrating

126
00:06:45.370 --> 00:06:50.550
that you are able to
manage your IT services

127
00:06:50.550 --> 00:06:56.259
in a way that is the most efficient and
effective for your organization.

128
00:06:57.410 --> 00:07:01.600
So it's a standard where
you are audited against

129
00:07:03.170 --> 00:07:07.800
your processes and your services,
to ensure that your processes and

130
00:07:07.800 --> 00:07:11.530
services are delivering
value to your organization,

131
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:16.170
that you have the right processes
in place in order to achieve this.

132
00:07:16.170 --> 00:07:21.260
But also, and when I say achieve this
I mean achieve value delivery, but

133
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:25.510
also that those processes work
efficiently and effectively.

134
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:29.840
That they're not bound down by
bureaucracy, that they're actually

135
00:07:29.840 --> 00:07:33.760
working in a way that will deliver
the most value to your organization.

136
00:07:35.770 --> 00:07:40.280
So ISO 20000 does not audit ITIL.

137
00:07:40.280 --> 00:07:42.280
This is not an ITIL audit.

138
00:07:43.290 --> 00:07:46.990
ITIL is just a best practice framework,
and there are lots of other frameworks.

139
00:07:46.990 --> 00:07:49.440
Even proprietary frameworks
that are out there.

140
00:07:49.440 --> 00:07:54.378
There are a lot of organizations
that have created proprietary

141
00:07:54.378 --> 00:07:56.527
frameworks for instance.

142
00:07:56.527 --> 00:07:57.385
And of course,

143
00:07:57.385 --> 00:08:01.610
what you evolve in your organization
becomes your proprietary framework.

144
00:08:01.610 --> 00:08:06.690
Now your proprietary management
framework will achieve ISO 20000,

145
00:08:06.690 --> 00:08:09.700
as long as it is efficient and

146
00:08:09.700 --> 00:08:15.210
it is effective in the processes and
the way that IT is managed.

147
00:08:16.290 --> 00:08:20.050
So there is a big
difference between the two.

148
00:08:20.050 --> 00:08:26.200
ISO 20000 is a standard for
the management of services.

149
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:31.700
Now, if you have implemented ITIL in
a way that is the best practice for

150
00:08:31.700 --> 00:08:37.539
your organization, then that will
help you to achieve ISO 20000.

151
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:41.391
I am not gonna tell you that
if you got ITIL implemented,

152
00:08:41.391 --> 00:08:44.130
then you're definitely
going to achieve ISO 20000.

153
00:08:44.130 --> 00:08:45.898
Cuz that's not the case.

154
00:08:45.898 --> 00:08:51.030
Cuz if you've got an ITIL framework
implemented in your organization.

155
00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:56.820
Then unless you have modified and
adapted that ITIL framework in a way that

156
00:08:56.820 --> 00:09:01.530
is the most efficient for you, then you're
not going to achieve ISO 20000 at all.

157
00:09:02.580 --> 00:09:08.760
You will only achieve ISO 20000 if
you can meet all of the requirements

158
00:09:08.760 --> 00:09:13.960
that are outlined in the ISO 20000,
we call them parts.

159
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:19.080
So these are the requirements
of ISO 20000.

160
00:09:19.080 --> 00:09:23.350
So ISO 20000, as I've said,
is something that you achieve.

161
00:09:24.860 --> 00:09:30.830
And it is something that you will have
an auditor come to your organization.

162
00:09:30.830 --> 00:09:34.630
And this is after you've had a lot of
time to prepare for this, by the way.

163
00:09:34.630 --> 00:09:40.350
And an auditor will look at your
processes and look at your environment.

164
00:09:40.350 --> 00:09:45.320
And look at the tools and
the management that you have in place, and

165
00:09:45.320 --> 00:09:46.720
the way that you work.

166
00:09:46.720 --> 00:09:51.070
And we'll assess whether you
have achieved all of the clauses

167
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:53.650
within the ISO 20000 requirement.

168
00:09:55.520 --> 00:10:01.500
So ISO 20000, as I've said,
is not dependent on ITIL at all.

169
00:10:01.500 --> 00:10:05.720
However, if you have an ITIL based
framework in place, and it's working

170
00:10:05.720 --> 00:10:10.840
efficiently and effectively, then it will
certainly help you to achieve ISO 20000.

171
00:10:10.840 --> 00:10:12.702
Cherokee, you have a question.

172
00:10:12.702 --> 00:10:16.745
>> Yeah, Jo, I know you've taught some
pretty high level courses here ITProTV.

173
00:10:16.745 --> 00:10:18.807
And just looking at the title for
this one,

174
00:10:18.807 --> 00:10:21.570
you're talking about the auditing process.

175
00:10:21.570 --> 00:10:23.666
Now this course that
we're about to get into,

176
00:10:23.666 --> 00:10:26.427
this isn't one that will prepare
us to be auditors, per se.

177
00:10:26.427 --> 00:10:30.147
But looking at the foundations, we want to
get a good understanding in order to be

178
00:10:30.147 --> 00:10:33.145
able to facilitate this implementation,
correct?

179
00:10:33.145 --> 00:10:37.560
>> Right, so what this course will do
is this course will prepare you for.

180
00:10:37.560 --> 00:10:40.530
>> It will tell you all about
the requirements for an ISO 20000 audit,

181
00:10:40.530 --> 00:10:41.555
as it were.

182
00:10:41.555 --> 00:10:42.880
Okay.

183
00:10:42.880 --> 00:10:44.280
So we use this course.

184
00:10:44.280 --> 00:10:47.790
And in fact, on this particular slide
that we've got in front of us now.

185
00:10:47.790 --> 00:10:51.170
We use this course,
just take a look at the target audience.

186
00:10:51.170 --> 00:10:56.636
We would use this course to prepare
people for an audit for ISO 20000.

187
00:10:56.636 --> 00:10:59.940
Perfect.
A lot of organizations will implement

188
00:10:59.940 --> 00:11:01.440
an ITIL based framework.

189
00:11:01.440 --> 00:11:05.240
And I won't say ITIL based framework,
cuz you never implement ITIL.

190
00:11:05.240 --> 00:11:07.380
You always implement ITIL based.

191
00:11:07.380 --> 00:11:11.990
And so what will happen is, organizations
get to a point where they perceive

192
00:11:11.990 --> 00:11:16.650
that they have implemented this framework,
and that it's working, great.

193
00:11:16.650 --> 00:11:19.100
And that they are working efficiently and
effectively.

194
00:11:19.100 --> 00:11:20.930
And so what do we do now, then?

195
00:11:20.930 --> 00:11:23.320
We can't demonstrate ITIL compliance.

196
00:11:23.320 --> 00:11:24.080
So what do we do?

197
00:11:24.080 --> 00:11:26.730
We wanna have that certificate,
we wanna have that plaque on the wall.

198
00:11:26.730 --> 00:11:28.282
>> Yeah, we wanna get some kind of.

199
00:11:28.282 --> 00:11:29.340
Recognition.
Recognition for

200
00:11:29.340 --> 00:11:31.290
our hard work that we've
put into everything.

201
00:11:31.290 --> 00:11:34.870
>> Right, and so
why the target audience for this is for

202
00:11:34.870 --> 00:11:39.210
those organizations that are saying,
okay, I wanna get some recognition now.

203
00:11:39.210 --> 00:11:40.720
How do I do this?

204
00:11:40.720 --> 00:11:45.850
And so it's at this point in time where an
organization might look for recognition,

205
00:11:45.850 --> 00:11:50.850
and the first place that they will come
to is the international standards.

206
00:11:50.850 --> 00:11:55.690
And your international standard,
your ISO 20000, will actually give them

207
00:11:55.690 --> 00:11:59.550
recognition for having a service
management framework in place.

208
00:11:59.550 --> 00:12:01.160
Not necessarily ITIL.

209
00:12:01.160 --> 00:12:03.900
But it's a management framework that

210
00:12:03.900 --> 00:12:09.610
will promote the delivery of
value to the business, itself.

211
00:12:09.610 --> 00:12:11.260
So the target audience for

212
00:12:11.260 --> 00:12:16.270
this are all those people who are going
to be involved in an ISO 20000 audit.

213
00:12:16.270 --> 00:12:20.330
So all of those people that
are preparing for an ISO 20000 audit.

214
00:12:20.330 --> 00:12:24.350
These are all of those people that
are gonna be involved in the actual

215
00:12:24.350 --> 00:12:25.980
audit process.

216
00:12:25.980 --> 00:12:28.890
And all of those people within IT.

217
00:12:28.890 --> 00:12:31.660
And it says here in that second
bullet point down underneath it,

218
00:12:31.660 --> 00:12:32.650
the target audience.

219
00:12:32.650 --> 00:12:35.790
It says managers,
team leaders, and other staff.

220
00:12:35.790 --> 00:12:38.675
>> Right, because I don't think it's
just isolated to the IT department.

221
00:12:38.675 --> 00:12:41.790
Those other stakeholders should
at least understand what

222
00:12:41.790 --> 00:12:44.530
they're approaching before the audit,
right?

223
00:12:44.530 --> 00:12:46.090
>> The biggest misconception for

224
00:12:46.090 --> 00:12:51.050
ISO 20000 is that we're just going to let
all the managers know what's going on.

225
00:12:51.050 --> 00:12:54.480
And as far as letting everybody else know,

Jo also explains the certification process and breaks down roles of the National Accreditation Bodies (NABs), Registered Certified Bodies (RCBs)  and more.
episodes.title: Standard Overview Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain what a  Service Management System is. The ladies cover what should be included within the SMS and explain that the service provider is responsible for continual improvement of the SMS. In addition to the "shalls" Jo also defines roles, the governance of processes, an example process model in and more!
episodes.title: Clause 4 - Service Management System

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue to cover the SMS. In line with the PDCA or deeming cycle the ladies encourage thought on the cyclic process.  They talk about improving the SMS and what type of considerations may help with planning.
episodes.title: Clause 4 - Service Management System Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain design and transition of new or changed services and their intent. First, they look at the service lifecycle to help explain what is going on during different phases of an organization. They also explain how changes can have a wide-reaching effect.
episodes.title: Clause 5 - Design and Transition

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee introduce Service Delivery. Jo explains how service delivery focuses on delivering the agreed services to the agreed service targets. She outlines the "shalls" and provides examples of what would be expected during an audit. A catalogue of services, documentation for a service, SLA components and service reporting index examples are explained.
episodes.title: Clause 6 - Service Delivery Processes

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo begin explaining Service continuity and availability management by defining key terms such as availability, service continuity and risk. The ladies look at an example of a service continuity management process. They also examine how monitoring, testing, budgeting, accounting and other factors contribute to the overall process.
episodes.title: Clause 6 - Service Delivery Processes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee explain the scope of the capacity management process. Jo states it  includes the planning and management of capacity for human, technical information and financial resources. She shares an example of capacity requirements  to help ensure that capacity requirements can be agreed, forecast and met.
episodes.title: Clause 6 - Service Delivery Processes Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo begin explaining the relationship processes. The ladies demonstrate how the relationship processes are responsible for managing the relationships with other parties.  Jo shares how the business relationship management (BRM) process aims to establish and maintain the relationship between the service provider and the customer(s).  They also discuss how the supplier management process is responsible for managing suppliers to ensure the provision of seamless, quality services.
episodes.title: Clause 7 - Relationship Processes

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee introduce incident and service request management. They explain how it differs from problem management. Key terminology is defined in addition to examples such as a Matrix of target times based on priorities .
episodes.title: Clause 8 - Resolution Processes

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo explain how the control processes: configuration management, change management, release and deployment management intact within an organization. They cover important terms such as configuration baseline, configuration item, CMDB, and request for change (RFC). In addition to breaking down these elements they also discus how configuration management intent.
episodes.title: Clause 9 - Control Processes

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee continue to look at control processes. They first cover configuration management and how it interacts with the CMDB. They next examine request for change and state this process should not be bureaucratic. They also examine components of Release and deployment management such as  example contents of a release policy.
episodes.title: Clause 9 - Control Processes Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo cover reiterate important take-aways. They make sure you understand the types of review, assessment and audit of a service management system, including service management, and the use of supporting systems, tools and techniques that enable an organization to plan and conduct reviews, assessments and internal audits of service management systems.
episodes.title: Audits and Certifications

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo continue to walk through the audit and certification process to help you be fully prepared for the process.
episodes.title: Audits and Certification Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Jo an Cherokee make sure you understand the approach to establishing and maintaining the SMS to ensure the required processes are effectively implemented, services are continually improved and the requirements of the ISO/IEC 20000-1 standard are met. Jo walks through the three phases and explains what to expect in each phase. Automation, tools and other tips are mentioned to help maintain continual improvement.
episodes.title: Achieving and Maintaining Certification

episodes.description: Tune in to watch as Jo gives Cherokee a pop quiz the cover sample exam questions.
episodes.title: Exam Review
